author: bolajija
title: Having Babies Around
body:
Different societies around the world have special 'customs' for the birth of a baby:

 â€¢ The Mbuti pygmies of the African rain forests tie a piece of jungle vibe around a new baby's waist. They attach a small piece of wood to the vibe to pass on the strength of the forest to the baby. 
  â€¢ The Ainu hunters of northern Japan make a tiny cut in a new baby's thigh. They dress the cut with fungi to pass on the magical power of sacred trees. 
          ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/0gl2yyvsqa.jpg). 
  â€¢ The Nootka tribe, from the northwest coast of North America, believe that twins are magical. If a family has twins, the parents and children are kept apart from the rest of the tribe for four years, so their. Magical properties will develop. 
             ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/8gqesbsre1.jpg). 
  â€¢ In many societies births are followed by a religious festival. In Christian countries babies are christened. They have the sign of the cross made on their forehead with holy water.

author: bolajija
title: Space oddities
body:
Although scientists know much about the Universe, there are still many strange thing in space that have not been fully explained black holes are the most mysterious. It seems that they exist, but they can never be seen ! 
     Anything that falls into a black hole can never come out again because gravity will crush it to nothing.   ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/x9o8q1th0m.jpg)
  BLACK HOLES
  Some very rare stars contain as much material as fifty or more suns. They are the brightest stars in the universe yet they turn into black holes- the blackest object in space 
1) when these stars die they keep on shrinking, because the pull of gravity is so strong 
2) They shrink down to a ting speck, called singularity or black hole 
3) Although tiny, the black hole contains all the material from the huge star
4 A black hole's gravity is so strong that no light can escape from it
5) Astronomers have not seen a black hole, but they have found stars they think may have a black hole nearby.  ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/1i61m0wa32.jpg)
>quote    
  Quasars are very distant that send out far more light than ordinary galaxies. They may also send out strong radio waves. 
    â€¢ Quasars seem to be sending out tremendous energy from a small space inside them. This could come from gas whirling around a gaint black hole at the centre of the galaxy. 
  â€¢ The name 'quasar' is short for quasi stellar (star-like) object.

author: bolajija
title: Zoo work
body:
â€¢ The Arabian oryx became extinct in the wild 20 years ago. Surviving oryx were reared in Arizona, USA, and the species is now back in the wild. 
 â€¢ several endangered monkey species have been bred in zoos. However, it is not always safe to release them back into the wild because their jungle homes are still being destroyed. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/ar0it9qqa2.jpg). 
 â€¢ The rare charham island black robin was saved from extinction by New Zealand wildlife experts, who used tom tits to foster the robin chicks. 
  â€¢ The South African quagga looked like a zebra. It was hunted for food until it died out.

author: bolajija
title: Fascinating fish
body:
Introduction 
The underwater world is full of strange surprises: 
â€¢ Thw Arawana lives in the flooded amazon rainforest it can jump up to 2 meters out of the water to feed on small birds or bats in the trees above. 
   â€¢ The African lungfish lives in mud at the bottom of dried-out swamps. It burrows into the ground and covers itself mucus to keep moist. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/bpdbj18y90.jpg). 
  â€¢ Dolphins, whales and porpoises talk to each other with clicking and whistling noises.
 â€¢ once the Female emperor penguins has laid an egg, the male keeps it warm by balancing it on his feet under a flap of skin.

author: bolajija
title: Ways of reproducing
body:
Here are the four basic ways that animals reproduce. 
 â€¢ The simplest forms of one-called animals, such as amoebae, reproduce by splitting themselves in half to from two identical creatures. Animals that behave in this way are called asexual 
   â€¢ some simple animals, such as sea corals and freshwater hydra, produce new creatures by budding. They grow a new branch which is a small version of the parent. Eventually the branch splits off to become a new individual. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/90uwh1hvo3.jpg). 
â€¢ Most animals have different male and female species. The male produces cells called sperm.the female produces egg cells called ova. The male sperm must join with the female egg before a new animal is produced. This method is called sexual reproduction.

author: bolajija
title: Plant life
body:
â€¢ The largest tree in the world is a giant sequoia growing in California. It is 84 metres tall and measures 29 meters round the trunk. 
â€¢The fastest-growing tree is the eucalyptus. It can grow 10 meters a year. 
 â€¢ The world's oldest trees are the bristlecone pines of California. One of them is about 4600 years old. 
    ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/kyirxsf1r4.jpg). 
  â€¢ The largest flower comes from the rafflesia plant. The flower can weigh 6kg and grow to a width of 91 cm. 
   â€¢ The largest forest in the world covers parts of Scandinavia and northern USSR and has a total area of over 9 million sq.k.m.

author: bolajija
title: Rivers
body:
Rivers begin high up on mountains and run downhill to the sea. They start from underground springs or melting glaciers. A river's route is divided into three parts. The first part is called the upper course, where the river flows steeply downhill and the current is fast. The water carries sand, gravel and rocks down with it. 
   ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/rfmv3q0jsd.jpg). 
    In the middle course the river flows along a gentler slope. It travels more slowly but it still wears away rock and sand from its banks. 
    In the lower course the river slows down and gets wider. The sand and rock it has been carrying are now worn down to tiny particles called silt.

author: bolajija
title: Coping in the cold
body:
In the winter months, when the weather is at its fiercest and food is hard to find, some mountain animals hibernate, which means that they sleep deeply for a long period of time. During hibernation: 
â€¢ body temperature drops. 
â€¢ The animals heartbeat slows down so that it uses up less energy. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/t4bm2wjhk0.jpg). 
 â€¢ The body fat reserve are gradually used up for nutrition. 
  â€¢ Eagles can fly very high. They glide on warm air currents called thermals to help lift them higher. Remain of steppe eagles have been found on n Mount Everest at heights of 7500 meters. It is thought that some eagles even fly right over Mount Everest. >quote

author: bolajija
title: Atmosphere
body:
The troposphere- height up to 16km over the Equator, 8km over the poles. This layer contains nearly all the water vapour and most of the other gases in the Other gases in the atmosphere. It gets colder with height. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/bpdbj18y90.jpg). 
 â€¢ The troposphere- height 8 to 50 km varies from place to place. This layer is cold, but the temperature increases with height. Within this layer is a band of ozone gas which filters out the sun harmful rays. 
   â€¢ The thermosphere - height 80 to 599 km. The temperature of this layer increases with height. At the top it is about 2200c

author: bolajija
title: The Past And The Future
body:
Here ar some examples of the shape of continents in the past : 
 â€¢ The Eastern coast of South America and the western coast of Africa were joined. Their modern shapes could fit together like a jigsaw. 
   â€¢ The continents of Africa and Antarctica were also joined. There is proof of this because fossilized remains of tropical African plants and animals have been found in modern Antarctica 
    ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/rfmv3q0jsd.jpg). 
 â€¢ part of California, including the city of Los Angeles, will have broken off from American. It will float north, past San Francisco on the mainland. 
  â€¢ African and Asia will have broken apart.

author: bolajija
title: Crust, mantle and core
body:
This is what the Earth might look like inside. At the centre Is the core, surrounded by the mantle. The crust is a thin outer layer. 
  â€¢ The Earth's core in about 7000 km across and is probably made of iron and nickel. The outer part is liquid and the inner part solid. 
       ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/bpdbj18y90.jpg). 
  â€¢ The mantle is made of rock. It contains most of the Earth's material. 
  â€¢ The crust is made of lighter rocks that floated to the top when Earth was molten it varies from 6 to 40 km thick.

author: bolajija
title: Strange but true
body:
â€¢ The oldest observatory building still standing is in Greece. It was built in about 100 b.c 
 â€¢ Anaxagoras, an early Greek philosopher, was banished for saying the sun was a red-hot stone. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/riic68874j.jpg). 
   â€¢ In 280 bc the Greek astronomer Aristarchus said the sun. Not Earth, was the centre of the solar system. It was more than 1800 years before he was proved right.
  â€¢ in 1609, Galileo made one of the first drawings of the moon's surface.

author: bolajija
title: Phases of the moon
body:
The moon keeps the same side facing Earth all the time, so we only see this one side of it. As the moon travels around the Eartg, we see a varying amount of this side each day. These different amounts, or stages, are called the phases of the moon. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/x9o8q1th0m.jpg)

  â€¢ when the moon is seen as a crescent. Only a sliver of the side facing earth is sunlit. 
 â€¢ As the moon moves round the earth, it appears half-lit and then finally fully lit (the full moon). At this stage the whole of the side facing earth in sunlit 
â€¢ it takes 29.5 days for the moon to move through all its phases from New, through,full, and back to new again.

author: bolajija
title: Strange but true
body:
â€¢ Venus' day is longer than its year. It takes 243 Earth days to spin once, and only 225 Earth days to go round the sun. 
 â€¢ Clouds on Venus spin round the planets in only four Earth days. 
â€¢ mars has a volcano called Olympus mons, that stretches 25km above the planets's surface. It is the largest volcano in the solar system. 
  Mars has two very small natural satellite, or moons, called Phobos and Deimos. Phones is 22 across. Deimos is 14 km across. 
â€¢ An atmosphere of mainly umbreathable carbon dioxide there are constant thunderstorms, with drops of sulphuric acid in the clouds.

author: bolajija
title: Detecting black holes
body:
Some binary star systems may contain a star that has turned into a black hole. Gas from the other star would swirl around the black hole before being pulled into it, giving off high- energy radiation, including x-rays. 

 â€¢ x-rays cannot travel through Earth's atmosphere, so they are studied by satellite that send information back to Earth. 
       ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/elu4fsuika.jpg). 
  â€¢.  A hot supergiant star in the Cygnus constellation has an invisible companion called Cygnus X-1. It is probably a black hole. 
  â€¢ There are many other suspected black holes, including a giant one at the centre of our galaxy.

author: bolajija
title: Detecting black holes
body:
Some binary star systems may contain a star that has turned into a black hole. Gas from the other star would swirl around the black hole before being pulled into it, giving off high- energy radiation, including x-rays. 

 â€¢ x-rays cannot travel through Earth's atmosphere, so they are studied by satellite that send information back to Earth. 
       ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/elu4fsuika.jpg). 
  â€¢.  A hot supergiant star in the Cygnus constellation has an invisible companion called Cygnus X-1. It is probably a black hole. 
  â€¢ There are many other suspected black holes, including a giant one at the centre of our galaxy.

author: bolajija
title: Neighboring galaxies
body:
The biggest galaxy in our group is the Andromeda spiral. It is about 2 million light- years away from earth and contains about 400 billion stars. 
  â€¢ Andromeda can be seen from Earth with the naked eye. 
     ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/8czkgqoa9l.jpg). 
   
Our nearest galaxy neighbours are the Magellanic Clouds. These are two small irregular galaxies. The larger galaxy contains about 10 billion stars and is 180,000 light-years away. The other galaxy is much smaller and further away. 
 â€¢ The Magellanic Clouds were first sighted in 1521 by the explorer Ferdinand Magellan.

author: bolajija
title: Orion The Hunter
body:
Some constellations. Such as Orion, belong to both the northern and the Southern Hemisphere. 
   â€¢ Orion was named after a famous hunter in Ancient Greek mythology. 
  â€¢ Betelgeuse is a variable red giant star, in Orion. 
  â€¢ Three star make up Orion's Belt. 
  â€¢ The horsehead Nebula, south of Orion, is a dark cloud of cold gas and dust shaped like a horse's head.
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/z52yulb57y.jpg). 
  â€¢ The African Dogon tribe say their ancestors knew about the invisible star Sirius B thousands of years before scientists discovered it in 1862

author: bolajija
title: The Electro-magnetic spectrum
body:
Stars give off different kinds of energy waves, or radiation. Each kind has a different wavelengths. Together they are called the electro-magnetic spectrum. 
  â€¢ we can see one kind of energy wave visible light. The others are invisible. 
    ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/55safzcsu3.jpg). 
  
   â€¢ special instruments are used to detect radiation. Dangerous X-rays and gamma rays are blocked by the Earth's atmosphere and are studied from space. 
   â€¢ Every star would explode if gravity did not hold its material together 
   â€¢ When you look at the sky at night, you are also looking back in time. The light from stars takes so long to reach Earth that what you see is how the star looked when their light began its journey to Earth centuries ago.

author: bolajija
title: Holy Objects
body:
In all religions,holy places and sacred objects are an important part of worship.

â€¢ copies of the Torah, the Jewish Goly law, are written in Hebrew on parchment scrolls and kept in a casket called the Ark. 

â€¢ St. Peter's in the Vatican City, Rome, was until recently, the world's largest Christian church. The largest church is now in the Ivory Coast, Africa. It was completed in 1988. 
           ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/ywaeml28dh.jpg). 
    â€¢ The ka'bah in Mecca Saudi Arabia, contains a sacred black stone. It is the most holy shrine of Islam. Many thousands of Muslims visit it each year. 
â€¢ statues of the Buddha decorate Buddhist temples and shrines.

author: bolajija
title: Seeing
body:
The eye has a special lining called the retina. This contains cells from that are sensitive to light. Messages from these cell pass along nerves to the brain, which works out what the eyes are looking at. 
 â€¢ The black centers of the eyes are called pupils. They are holes that let in light. 
   
      ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/i9ylk6sz8z.jpg). 

    â€¢ Behind the pupil is a lens. It focuses light rays into an upside- down picture on the retina inside the back of the eyeball. The brain turns the image the right way up. 
    â€¢ An adult's brain weighs about 1.4 kg. It is roughly the size and shape of a cauliflower.

author: bolajija
title: Hearing
body:
The part of the ear you can see is called the outer ear. The collects and funnels sounds into the inner ear. Inside the inner ear: 
  â€¢ The sounds make the eardrum vibrate, or shake. The vibrations from pass on through two small bones called the hammer and the anvil, and then through a group of three tiny bones called the stirrup. 
             ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/9aghg5c2hw.jpg). 
  â€¢ Finally the vibrations reach a coiled tube called the cochlea. This is filled with liquid and line with tiny hairs connected to nerve endings These pass messages about the vibrations to the brain. 
  â€¢ one brain cell may be connected to as many as 25,000 other brain cells that is connected to the ear organ

author: bolajija
title: Forests
body:
â€¢ Some medicines are made from forest trees. For instance, quinine, which is used to treat malaria, comes originally from a chemical found in the bark of the cinchona tree. 
â€¢ Only 1 per cent of sunlight reaches the rainforest floor. 
â€¢ The USA, USSR, china and Malaysia are amongst the top producers of hardwood. 
   Here are five types of deciduous trees(i.e. they lose their leaves in autumn): 
â€¢ Ash â€¢ Maple â€¢ Birch â€¢ Oak â€¢ Chestnut 
    ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/crtpuqpw0q.jpg). 
â€¢ Lianas are strong rope-like rainforest plants. They can grow to a width of 2 meters and are strong enough to swing on. 
â€¢ The largest forest in the world covers parts of Scandinavia and northern USSR and has a total area of over 9 million sq. km.

author: bolajija
title: Saving The Earth
body:
Scientists estimate that the Earth's average temperature could rise by as much as 2-4C by the year 2030.  If the earth's temperature does rise, the ice sheets could melt and flood many coastal Rey. 
  â€¢ Over 4 million cars in Brazil are now running on gasohol instead of petrol Gasohol is a fuel made from sugar cane 
â€¢ 1096- A typhoon killed 50.000 people in Hong Kong. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/nqvbw85hj9.jpg). 
â€¢ 1955- In the USA, 200 people were killed by a hurricane. 
â€¢ 1962- An avalanche in Peru killed 3000 people. 
â€¢ 1970- In Bangladesh a cyclone and tidal waves killed 20,000 people. 
â€¢ 1975- lightning in Zimbabwe killed 21 people. 
  What is the world ðŸŒŽ turning to life are losing from different countries safe us all our lord.

author: bolajija
title: Oceans
body:
â€¢ The oceans make up 97 per cent of the Earth's water. 
â€¢ Most of an iceberg is hidden underwater. Only 10 per cent of its floats above the surface.  
 â€¢ The greatest difference in tides is in the Bay of funds in Canada. The difference between low tide and high tides is about 16.5 meters. 
 â€¢ The highest underwater mountain is in the ocean between samoaeanf New Zealand. Its summit is 8690 metres above the seabed. 
    ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/t5scgx7gjk.jpg).
 â€¢ The White Sea, in the USSR, has the lowest temperature, only-2â€¢C. 
â€¢ The Persian Fulf is the is the warmest sea. In the summer its temperature reaches 35.6C 
â€¢ The most salty sea in the world is the Dead Sea, in the Middle East.

author: bolajija
title: Uranus
body:
Introduction 
             
           Uranus was discovered in 1781 by William Herschel, an amateur astronomer, using a home-made telescope. At first he thought he had found a comet.   The diameter of Uranus is 51,000 km. It's day is about 17 hours long, and it takes 84 Earth years to travel round the sun.  
             ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/3lowssl0br.jpg). 
   â€¢ Uranus is made up mostly of hydrogen and helium. The gas methane is also present in its atmosphere, which makes Uranus look green from Earth. 
  â€¢ until 1986, only nine rings had been counted round Uranus. On its fly-past however, voyager 2 found four more rings, making 13 in all. 
                   Uranus' satellites
   Uranus has 15 satellites altogether. The five main ones are Miranda, Ariel, umbriel, Titania and Oberon. The largest, oberon and Titania, are about 1500 km across. 
â€¢ Uranus spins on its side instead of almost upright,like the other planets. Because of this, the poles of the planet can sometimes face the sun. When this happens, they are warmer than the planet,s equator!  
  â€¢ Uranus' small satellite Miranda may have been shattered in a collision with another body. It seems to have broken up into large pieces which collected together again.

author: bolajija
title: Ten Famous Children's Books And Ten Great Writes
body:
Introducing: 
                   
 â€¢Hans Christian Andersen:- Fairy Tales (including The emperor's New clothes). 
â€¢   J M Barrie :- Peter Pan. 
â€¢ Lewis Carroll:- Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. 
â€¢ Clive king:- sting of the Dump. 
â€¢ Rudyard Kipling:- The Jungle book 
â€¢ can lewis :- The Lion, the witch and the wardrobe. 
â€¢ A A Milne:- Winnie-the-pooh. 
â€¢ R L Stevenson:- Treasure island. 
â€¢ Mark Twain:- The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn. 
â€¢ Roald Dahl:- The BFG.
         ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/5ylddfsj86.jpg)     >quote    
     Ten Great Writers. 

 Here is a note of the ten great writers and one of their best-known works: 

â€¢ Jane Austen :- pride and prejudice 
â€¢ charlotte Bronte:- Jane Eyre 
â€¢ Emily Bronte:- Wuthering Heights 
â€¢ Miguel de Cervantes:- Don Quixote 
â€¢ Geoffrey Chaucer:- Canterbury Tales
â€¢ Dante:- Divine comedy 
â€¢ Charles Dickens:- Great expectations, Oliver Twist 
â€¢ Dostoevsky:- crime and punishment 
â€¢ Herman Melville:- moby Dick 
â€¢ Tolstoy:- war and peace.
root_title: Ten Famous Children's Books And Ten Great Writes

author: bolajija
title: Pioneers Of Astronomy
body:
Many ancient astronomers added a great deal to our understanding of space. Some were persecuted for discoveries because they went against the teachings of the Christian church. 
        ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/74vvf4br9m.jpg). 
   â€¢ Nicolaus Copernicus (1474-1543) was a polish astronomer and mathematician. He published a book that said the sun, not Earth was the centre of the solar system. His book was officially banned until 1835. 
 â€¢ Ptolemy of Alexandria was born in ad120. He believed that Earth was at the centre of  the solar system and that the sun, moon and planets circled round it. 
  â€¢ Ptolemy's idea of the solar system was accepted for 1300 years. 
      ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/nqvbw85hj9.jpg). 
  â€¢ Tycho Brahe (1546-1601) was a danish astronomer. He wrongly placed Earth back in the centre of the solar system but accurately observed and measured stars, planets and comets. 
 â€¢ Galileo was one of the first to use a telescope. This is one of his instruments, which he built soon after telescopes were invented at the beginning of the seventeenth century. He even made thme lenses himself. The most powerful of his telescopes magnified, or enlarged, an object thirty times.

author: bolajija
title: Ancient Astronomy
body:
Introduction:                                                                

        From early times, people have been interested in the star and planets. They have tried to understand space and how it affects human life. Great stone circles, such as Stonehenge in England (built about 3500 years ago) may have been used to study how the sun and moon moved through the sky. 
       More than 2000 years ago, the Chinese, Egyptians, Babylonian and Greeks were all skilled astronomers. 
           ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/ywaeml28dh.jpg). 
     The Babylonians: 
  About 3000 years ago, the babylonians (who used to live in what is now Iraq ) studied the star. They invented astrology- the belief that people's lives are influenced by the position of the star and planets. 
  
â€¢ This Babylonian boundary stone shows the importance of the sun, moon and planets to this ancient civilization. 
â€¢ The Babylonians invented the twelve signs of the zodiac that are still used in astrology.

author: bolajija
title: Miscellany
body:
![image](https://img.esteem.ws/bkd6n98pya.jpg). 
 
  A scientist has calculated that about 60 billion people died between the years 40,000b.c. and 1990. This means that about 9 percent of all people who have ever lived are alive today!
  â€¢ if the age of the Earth (4.6 billion years) is likened to a single year, the following events take place on 31 December, the last day of the year:      ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/5b2g0h1xb3.jpg). 
   4.15 pm : Appearance of humanlike beings
   11.10 pm : Arrival of earliest inhabitants in Europe 
    14 seconds before midnight: Birth of Christ 
 
 â€¢ using this same comparison, the life span of someone who lived to be 120 years old would be just three- fourths of a second.

author: bolajija
title: Crime and conflict
body:
![image](https://img.esteem.ws/x9o8q1th0m.jpg). 
â€¢ The number of prisoners in the United States at the end of 1990 reached a record high of 77,243. 
â€¢ A survey in 1986 showed that more than 8 people per 100,000 in the USA were murdered that year. That was twice as many as in the next highest countries in the survey- Hungary, Israel, and Australia. Norway had the fewest murders. 
      During world war l, more than a million soldiers were killed or wounded at first battle of the Somme in 1916 l. 
 â€¢ About 2.5 million people died at the battle of Stalingrad in 1942-43, fought between the Germans and the Russians during world war ll. 
  â€¢ in all, about 55 million people were killed during world war ll. Almost half of these people were from the USSR. 

 These countries fought each other in the two world wars.

author: bolajija
title: Punishment
body:
A person found guilty of a crime is punished. This a intended to stop them offending again, and to discourage other people from committing crimes.  
![image](https://img.esteem.ws/x74xoy3gzt.jpg). 
   â€¢ Imprisonment: criminal are locked in jail, away from society. 
  â€¢ Fines: offenders pay for their crimes by handing over a sum of money. 
â€¢ community service: Offenders are not imprisoned, but they are made to work for the community. 
  â€¢ probation: Offender are not imprisoned but their behavior is regularly checked by officials called probation officers 
                    ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/z52yulb57y.jpg). 
   â€¢ Death penalty: in China, South Africa,Turkey,Iran,Saudi Arabia,Malaysia and 38 states of the USA murderers are put to death. 
â€¢ In Australia and Britain the death penalty has been kept for those who commit treason.

author: bolajija
title: Marriage as agreement
body:
Marriage is an agreement to live together made by a man and a woman. The wedding or marriage ceremony is important in many religions. It is usually a time go celebration. 
      ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/wdqwdlslg4.jpg). 
   â€¢ In most societies, people hypne marriage partner at a time. This is called monogamy. In a societies such as Australia,Canada,Europe and the United States, most people are free to choose who they want to marry. In some places, such as India and the Middle East, parechoose marriage partners for their children. 
  â€¢ In a few societies, men can have more than one wife at a time. This is called polygamy. 
  ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/198ehtcgaj.jpg). 
    A common-law marriage is when a couple live together as husband and wife but do not go through a legal or religious marriage ceremony. 
â€¢ some married couples decide that they are not happy living together. In many societies they can end the marriage by getting divorced.

author: bolajija
title: Plant Around The World
body:
Botanists divide the Earth into six different regions called biomes. Each biome is characterized by particular types of plants that grow there. The main biomes and shown below.             ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/kyirxsf1r4.jpg)

  â€¢ Tropical rainforests cover about 6% of the Earth. They grow in a belt around the Equator. Because there is so much rain in these areas there is a rich variety of plants, more than in any other region in the world. Jungle trees are evergreen,which means they don't shed their leaves. 
  â€¢ North of the jungle areas there are temperate forests of bushy-shaped broad-leaves trees. These are deciduous,which means they shed their leaves in autumn and grow new ones in spring.      ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/t5scgx7gjk.jpg)

   â€¢ North of the temperate forests there is a huge belt of coniferous forest which cover half of the earth. Coniferous trees are good at surviving the cold. They have tough waxy evergreen needles instead of broad leaves. 
  â€¢ North of the coniferous forest lies the tundra, an area where th ground is permanently frozen a few centimeters beneath the surface. There isn't enough soul for large trees to grow here. Instead there are carpets of moss and tiny flowers. 
  â€¢ Grasslands are areas where it is too dry for forest to grow but there is enough rain to stop the land being a desert. Carpets of tough grass grow here, weathering warm summers and cold winters. Grassland near the Equator are called savanna.  ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/pjcaakq2c9.jpg)

â€¢ A fifth of the Earth's surface is desert, where there is little or no rainfall. Plants which grow here must be able to survive in drought conditions. Many of them have waterproof leaves and thick rubbery flesh for storing moisture.

author: bolajija
title: Wars
body:
Wars have been waged throughout history. This are some of the fact about welfare:-
 â€¢ in the last 5500 years there have been only 392 years when no known war was being fought somewhere in the world. 
  â€¢ world war ll also saw the greatest loss of life of any war. About 54 million people died. 
 â€¢ The longest war was fought between England and France it lasted 115 years, from 1338 to 1453. 
      ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/x9o8q1th0m.jpg). 
 â€¢ world war ll (1939-1945) cost approximately Â£1050 billion. That is more than all the world's previous war put together. 
  It is estimated that in 1988 the amount spent on weapons throughout the world was Â£460 billion. That is equal to Â£72 for every person.    The shortest war on record lasted for just 38 minutes on 27 August 1896. It was fought between the U.k. and Zanzibar (now Tanzania).

author: bolajija
title: Weapons
body:
Warfare has changed over the centuries. Here are some of the weapons people have invented to defend themselves and attack others: 
â€¢ Hand weapons are used for stabbing or hitting. They are the oldest group of weapons, and include clubs, swords and spears. 
  Catapults are early examples of shooting weapons. Guns and cannons came later. Modern versions include machine-guns, torpedoes and guided missiles. 
    ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/x9o8q1th0m.jpg). 
    â€¢ booby- traps weapons probably originated from animal-trapping methods. Modern booby-traps includes land mines that explode when touched. 
  Modern bombs include the devastating nuclear bomb, which can poison the atmosphere with radiation. >quote

author: bolajija
title: World  Climates And Seasons
body:
The world is divided into different types of climate. They are 
 â€¢polar  â€¢ temperate â€¢ subtropical â€¢ tropical 
   ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/dg5mwcxunl.jpg)
â€¢ polar constantly cold; the land and sea are covered by thick ice sheets. 
  â€¢ Temperate changeable weather, with warm dry summers and mild winters. 
 â€¢ subtropical warm, with alternate dry and rainy seasons. 
  â€¢Tropical constant hot temperatures and daily rain showers Never any seasonal changes. 
  Seasons : The season are caused by the Earth's orbits. For a few months each year half the Earth is tilted towards. the sun and gets strong heat rays, whilst the other half is tilted away and gets weak rays. 
 The position is gradually reversed through the year. When it is summer in one hemisphere it is winter in the other. In autumn and spring the two hemispheres are an equal distance from the rays

author: bolajija
title: New sources of power
body:
The world's supplies of coal, gas, and oil are being used up rapidly as cities and industries develop. In the future, people may learn how to use new sources of power that do not run out: 
 â€¢ wind power : electricity can be generated by using windmills that turn simply by the power of the wind.  
  â€¢ water power : experiments are taking place to find out how to use the power of the world's oceans and rivers to produce electricity 
 â€¢ New fuels: these can be made from tiny algae plant, from alcohol, and even from animal drug.  ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/y4z6fi23nb.jpg)
â€¢ solar power: the sun's rays can be used to produce power on earth 
â€¢ Nuclear fusion: by joining atoms together, enormous amounts of power could be generated. This would be safer than the atomic power in use now.

author: bolajija
title: Feathers And bird
body:
Birds feathers are made from keratin, a substance which is also found in hair and horn. 
  Down the middle of a feather there is a stiff horny shaft called a quill. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/lqe6ypm40c.jpg)
  â€¢ The flat part on either side of the quill is called the vane. It is made from tiny fibers called barbs. There are about 600 barbs on either side, each carrying smaller offshoots. All the barbs and offshoots are locked tightly together by hooks to make a smooth surface. 
 ![image](https://img.esteem.ws/k2ywp5hu4v.jpg).
Water birds have long legs for wading. They often have webbed feet to help them paddle, and long bills or breaks for finding food in the water. Cormorants , ducks and flamingoes are example of waterbirds * item
